title: HSBC Report 10% Rise In First Half Pre-Tax Profit
text:
View Photo 

Profit before tax at the UK's largest bank has risen by 10% to £8.7bn in the first 6 months of the year. 
The profit rise came off the back off a 6% increase in revenue to £21.1bn. 
These results for the first half of the financial year come a little over a month since HSBC announced that it would axe up to 8,000 jobs in the UK as part of a global restructuring. 
On that same investor call in June the bank also outlined its plans to exit its Turkish and Brazilian operations, the latter of which it has confirmed this morning as it reveals the sale of its Brazilian subsidiary to Bradesco for $5.2bn (£3.3bn). 
This move sees the bank move further away from its once global ambition to be the "world's local bank". It does still, however, employ nearly 270,000 people in 72 countries. 
Stuart Gulliver, HSBC's boss, who took the helm in 2011 praised the performance of its Asian operations; "strong revenue performance across our Asia businesses helped drive increased profits and Global Banking and Markets had a good six months". 
HSBC is currently toying with the idea of relocating its headquarters away from the UK. The fact that its Asia business is continuing to perform strongly will add further clout to the argument for it to relocate back to Hong Kong. 
The group expect to announce a decision by the end of the year, and stress that any change would take two years to execute. 
On the investor call in June HSBC revealed that it expected 80% of its profit before tax in the future to come from Asia as it looks to focus on Gunagdong region of China, which it views as a new 'silk road': "we think there is an opportunity to create another Hong Kong in Guangdong”, it said. 
Today's results also revealed a provision of just over $1.1bn (£0.7m) as regulatory settlements continue to haunt the bank. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in the bank have fallen over 8% in the last 12 months.
